text:
Really interesting and thought provoking article about technical innovation. Curious to hear what this crew thinks about it:

<http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jul/22/the-tech-utopia-nobody-wants-why-the-world-nerds-are-creating-will-be-awful>

Do you, as an individual, think much about the aggregate effect of our new ideas on our culture and wellbeing as a whole, or do you just think "wow, that's a cool idea... let's make it." (Not sure I even have a good answer to that myself.)

attachments.title: The tech utopia nobody wants: why the world nerds are creating will be awful
attachments.text: JR Hennessy: If you don't think welfare should be replaced by high-nutrient sludge, or are irritated by Google Glass, you're not backwards – you're a human being
attachments.fallback: the Guardian: The tech utopia nobody wants: why the world nerds are creating will be awful

text: Umm - I'll only speak for myself - but all I think about is the effect it has on the people who use it
" The geeks, with their ready willingness to abandon social norms, are pulling us toward a utopia nobody wants."
I think thats the main point: people wont go to where they dont want to be
I think the article is a little alarmist
On the flip side we do have thinks like FB that found a way to infiltrate into our everyday lives.
well - only to the extent that you use FB
Google Glass does not project data directly onto the retina.
It's not just me anymore, it's a system that millions of people use.
well - what I mean is: we all have a choice

I would say the data mining that people are unaware of (or at least they are unaware of how much of their information is tracked and sold) is WAY scarier that the dorks who invented a high nutrition sludge so they didn't have to waste time eating actual food.  As Justin rightly points out, you can't make people want things they don't want.  But you can cloak what you want (endless information about people) in the guise of "friendship" like Facebook does.

And I'm not singling Facebook out.  As we all know, our beloved friends at Google know insane amounts about all of us and sell it all the time to anyone willing to pay for it.  No free social network or search engine is actually free.
Google Glass is about as harmful as Laser Tag
And about as geeky
Maybe it's just me but the there's choice and there's the illusion of choice. IMO.

You could opt to ride your bike everywhere and not drive a car, for example. But if roads, public transportation and other public entities are set up in a way to encourage car driving the choice isn't that simple anymore. I think we're slowly doing the same thing for tech and social media services.

What about situations in which choice is limited? For example, the idea of replacing foods stamps with Soylent. That, in my mind, is a somewhat dehumanizing act that would be inflicted on people with potentially little choice in that situation. I guess you could argue that Soylent might be nutritionally better than the hotdogs and doritos that might be otherwise bought with foodstamps?
The idea that the world is going to rack and ruin is as old as humanity.

but I think the food stamps/soylent a false dichotomy - we're veering into socio-political territory here that is probably best handled after work - but for the sake of this conversation, we have unlimited choices
<http://thedailyshow.cc.com/videos/w95a3v/glass-half-empty>

attachments.title: Glass Half Empty
attachments.text: Jason Jones investigates an emerging form of discrimination that Google Glass 'explorers' in San Francisco must face. (5:12)

text: Oh Jason Jones
Im not going to lie - I loved that bit
So this is pretty cool. <http://beautifuldecay.com/2014/08/22/norman-rockwells-reference-photos-iconic-paintings-revealed/>

attachments.title: Norman Rockwell's Reference Photos For His Iconic Paintings Revealed
attachments.text: Norman Rockwell (1894–1978) was a celebrated 20th-century American painter and illustrator, whose works became the imagery depicting everyday life in the States. It appears, Rockwell's photo-realistic artworks were often accompanied by staged photographs which artist then used as a re
attachments.fallback: Beautiful/Decay Artist & Design: Norman Rockwell's Reference Photos For His Iconic Paintings Revealed

text: <!channel>: has anyone seen an Amazon package come through addressed to John? We ordered a couple cables that said they were delivered Friday at noon but we can't find them anywhere in the office.
<!channel>: Also, I have 7 out of 8 Samsung Tablets accounted for, but one is floating. Please let me know asap if you can see or know of it's whereabouts
tablet is accounted for, cables are still a mystery
